executive_summary: Revenue for the Mayonnaise Production industry has increased over the five years to 2021 even amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, with industry revenue increasing 11.5% in 2020 alone. Mayonnaise remains the most popular and most used condiment in the United States and is consumed by many as a side for sandwiches, hamburgers and salads, among other food types. Over the past five years, the health consciousness trend has forced operators to adjust their product mix to remain competitive.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry benefited from increasing consumer disposable income
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Mayonnaise Production industry has benefited from increasing consumer disposable income over the five years to 2021. Furthermore, industry revenue increased 11.5% in 2020 alone as consumers chose industry products over more expensive alternatives.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Mayonnaise remains ubiquitous as a condiment in the US
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Within the United States, mayonnaise remains ubiquitous as a condiment and is consumed by many as a side for sandwiches, hamburgers and salads, among other food types. In fact, the mayonnaise consumption market is more than twice as large as any other condiment market in the United States.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, industry revenue is expected to continue growing, albeit at a slower rate. As the economy continues to improve from coronavirus-induced lows, consumers' disposable income is expected to continue rising, spurring demand for industry products to grow at the retail level.

Product innovation is expected to play an important role in improving the performance of this industry over the coming years. Overall, industry revenue is expected to grow at an annualized rate of 0.3% to $2.0 billion over the five years to 2026.

industry_definition: Mayonnaise manufacturers make the spread out of eggs, oil, vinegar and various other ingredients. Mayonnaise is used in prepared foods such as sandwiches and can be purchased separately for use at home in a variety of dishes.
key_trends: The shift in product offerings is one of the main reasons why mayonnaise sales have experienced headwinds
Exports to Latin American countries have provided some industry operators with a boost in export revenue
Over the past five years, the cost of many primary inputs have been subject to heavy volatility
New product introductions will likely help maintain revenue from grocery stores
Product innovation is expected to play an important role in improving the performance of this industry
The prices of key inputs are anticipated to rise at a steady, but moderate rate
Health consciousness has risen in the past decade, forcing many operators to introduce new products

market_segmentation.segment_description: According to data provided by the Association for Dressings and Sauces, the largest purchasers of mayonnaise at the end consumer level is younger buyers below the age of 35. This group accounts for an estimated 39.3% of industry revenue.

Consumers in the middle age bracket have higher incomes than their older counterparts but are less apt to seek out the value-added, higher-priced products their younger counterparts are more prone to purchasing. As a result, they are a larger market than those above 55 but a smaller market than those below 35, representing an estimated 29.7% of industry revenue in 2021.

Baby boomers and other consumers aged 55 and older are the least likely to purchase mayonnaise by a significant margin. Industry products are highly discretionary and are not considered essential grocery purchases, which makes them more likely to be cut from grocery budgets as income levels fall. Consumers above the age of 55 have a lower average income than their younger counterparts, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Additionally, this market segment is less likely to be actively pursuing a more healthful lifestyle, which makes them less likely to purchase the healthier industry products that are sold at a higher price point. As a result, purchasing mayonnaise is less prominent in this age bracket and is forecast to represent 18.4% of industry revenue in 2021.

Exports make up a significant share of industry revenue, which is estimated at 12.6% of industry revenue in 2021. Industry operators mainly export their products to Canada and Mexico due to close proximity and favorable trade terms with these countries.

products_and_services.product_description: Brand-name products, such as Hellman's or Kraft Foods Group Inc., have long been the standard bearers of mayonnaise in the domestic market. These brands are part of the product portfolios of large, multinational companies that are well-funded and have achieved significant economies of scale that have enabled them to achieve success in the industry.
Currently, brand-name products account for the vast majority of industry revenue, at an estimated 72.2%. Private-label alternatives account for the remaining share of industry revenue.
Other non-branded or generic mayonnaise products account for only 7.8% of the market.

tier_1_suppliers: Chicken Egg Production in the US
Orange & Citrus Groves in the US
Seasoning, Sauce and Condiment Production in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Paper Bag & Disposable Plastic Product Wholesaling in the US
Margarine & Cooking Oil Processing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Fast Food Restaurants in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Industry operators are reliant upon the performance of their downstream markets. Grocery wholesalers, retailers, food service establishments and, most importantly, consumers represent the downstream customers for the industry. Lower activity in these industries is likely to result in declining demand for industry products, which often leads to lower order volumes.

An increase in the health of the domestic consumers tends to bring about heightened demand for industry products. Mayonnaise is a discretionary product and when per capita disposable income levels rise, demand for mayonnaise grows, as consumers have more money to spend on nonessential products. Per capita disposable income has risen over the past five years, increasing an annualized 2.2% during the five-year period to 2021, boosting demand for mayonnaise and other discretionary grocery items.

The rise of supercenters such as Walmart Inc. and Target Corporation in the grocery and food retailing space has shifted much of demand for mayonnaise from smaller grocers and wholesalers to these retail giants. These companies have enough purchasing power to keep prices low for consumers, which spurs demand for discretionary groceries but can lower industry selling prices.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports are expected to account for just 2.0% of domestic Mayonnaise Production industry demand in 2021, down from 3.0% in 2016. Over recent years, the American palate has expanded to include tastes and flavors from around the world, yet mayonnaise has not changed dramatically in taste.

In 2021, exports are expected to account for 12.6% of revenue, down from 14.6% in 2016. Exports are becoming an increasingly significant contributor to industry revenue. Over the five years to 2021, exports are measured to decline at an annualized rate of 0.6% to $247.4 million.

business_locations.location_description: The West region of the US is home to the largest number of industry establishments, accounting for 23.2% of establishments. This region has access to several major port cities in addition to being located near high concentrations of the US population.

The Southeast region has the second-highest concentration of industry locations and is estimated to account for 20.9% of all industry establishments. This area provides access to key raw materials while producers can also service large markets such as Miami and Atlanta. This region is also generally inexpensive in terms of land, enabling operators to set up large production establishments are relatively low costs.

The Great Lakes is estimated to account for 16.5% of the industry's manufacturing facilities. Illinois and Wisconsin dominate the region, each accounting for an estimated 6.1% and 3.1% of total industry establishments, respectively. Michigan (3.6%) and Ohio (2.8%) also account for a significant portion of regional establishments, due to the presence of big cities such as Detroit and Cleveland, in addition to the area's favorable growing conditions.

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to some of the country's biggest and most affluent cities, such as New York, Boston and Washington, DC. This makes the region very attractive to manufacturers as these cities are home to a large concentration of the population and have access to many major highways and ports. New York has the second-most industry establishments per state with 7.0%. Altogether the Mid-Atlantic region comprises 14.0% of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA has specific standards that mayonnaise must meet in terms of being an emulsified semi-solid made of egg/egg by-product and at least 65% vegetable oil.
The FDA governs food production and labeling standards through acts like the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act.
The EPA enforces environmental regulations like the Clean Water Act and Clean Air Act related to wastewater discharge and pollution prevention.

barriers_points.barrier_description: One of the leading challenges new entrants contend with is the well-entrenched position of the industry's larger players, Unilever and Kraft Foods Group Inc. These two companies account for roughly 70.0% of the industry and have established relationships with grocers across the country and their established brand names make them more difficult to compete with on a large scale.

For smaller players, establishing links with large retail outlets is crucial for generating initial sales. Retailers place popular branded products in optimal areas with the most visibility. New players may not be able to obtain shelf space or be placed in areas with low visibility within the store.

basis_points.basis_description: Price plays a significant factor in competition between manufacturers. Mayonnaise is a discretionary grocery item and producers must price their goods at a level that corresponds with what downstream consumers are willing to pay.
Product quality is another important point of differentiation for manufacturers. Consumers noted that quality was the most important determining factor in their mayonnaise choice.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Unilever and Kraft Foods Group Inc. account for roughly 70.0% of industry revenue. These brands are nearly synonymous with mayonnaise for American consumers and are both backed by diversified, multibillion-dollar corporations.
The emergence of private-label and niche brands has created more space for new companies to enter the industry and thrive.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Prices of key production inputs, such as eggs, vegetables, fruits, fats and oils are the primary drivers of overall purchase costs. These costs have been volatile over the past five years and most drivers have experienced an overall increase in price, mainly due to volatility in 2020 amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

Purchases also include packaging materials, such as glass jars and flexible plastic, which are needed for distribution. Over the five years to 2021, the price of plastic materials and resin has decreased at an annualized rate of 0.1%.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although labor is needed for tasks like packaging and distribution, producers primarily use machinery to automate processes as much as possible to compete with large players in the consolidated industry.
Over the past five years, capital intensity has declined from $0.29 in 2016 to $0.26 in 2020 as major automation investments were made earlier in the period when the technology was newer.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility is high due to fluctuations in the cost of raw materials like eggs, vegetables, fruits, fats and oils.
Changes in per capita consumption of foods typically consumed with mayonnaise like meat, poultry, fish or salad also affect demand for the industry's products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Adoption of computerized processes, automation, computer-aided manufacturing and quality assurance programming has helped boost product quality and uniformity.
New technologies like sub-surface dispersion machinery and tight control of oil droplet size have become common to maintain consistency in the emulsification process.
Packaging technologies like canning, refrigeration, drying and chemical preservation have improved to ensure freshness of perishable products.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Companies that produce a variety of condiments are able to hedge downturns in consumption of mayonnaise. However, changes in demand of mayonnaise directly impact revenue for this industry.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Although mayonnaise is a discretionary item, it is inexpensive and many consumers will continue eating mayonnaise in economic downturns.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of food and eggs have been volatile over the past five years, making it hard for companies to pass on price changes to consumers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Many large companies have looked at acquiring smaller operations that specialize in niche segments.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automation has been important for companies that produce mayonnaise. Automation has enabled higher production for lower wage costs, especially among larger companies.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as sealing and packing machinery?
FAQs.answer: As mayonnaise is an egg-based product, companies must use the most recent technology for packaging to ensure the product does not go bad.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Imported mayonnaise is subject to various import tariffs, depending on the country that it is coming from. Many of these tariffs have been unchanged for a number of years.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with FDA standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies must comply with food safety and food handling regulations from the FDA. These are especially important for egg-based products that would carry diseases such as Salmonella.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Large companies, especially those with predominant brand names often have higher profit due to their economies of scale.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: The volatility of input costs negatively effect industry profit as operators cannot pass on changes in costs to consumers in the short run.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? Have you had any issues securing or keeping contracts?
FAQs.answer: Reliable contracts with suppliers of key raw materials considerably reduce supply volatility. Guaranteed supplies at fixed prices minimize supply costs and aid production planning.

FAQs.question: What has your company done to increase economies of scale? How do you plan to further increase economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators benefit from economies of scale, which enable producers to spread costs over a large volume and variety of products, reducing per-unit costs.

FAQs.question: What kind of arrangements do you currently have? Do you incur high distribution costs?
FAQs.answer: Ensuring that distribution channels are used to their optimal capacity maximizes sales and reduces distribution costs.

FAQs.question: How can you adapt to changing consumer preferences and the rising health trend? How do you plan to mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: As more consumers follow a healthy diet, represented by an increase in the healthy eating index, demand for fatty products such as mayonnaise is likely to decline.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is derived from demand from food establishments? How will this affect your company?
FAQs.answer: When demand from food services and drinking places rises, so does demand for industry products.

FAQs.question: Do you track per capita disposable income? How will you take advantage of rising incomes?
FAQs.answer: The level of disposable income affects the type of grocery products that consumers purchase and how often they dine at restaurants.
